newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan port shutdown stalls crude tanker.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan port shutdown stalls crude tanker.

text.p: The shutdown of northern Taiwan's main oil offloading port has stalled a tanker carrying 300,000 tonnes of African crude, officials of state-run Chinese Petroleum said on Monday.
The tanker, identified as the Vanadas, had been scheduled to unload its 300,000-tonne shipment at the weekend but could not do so due to the shutdown, Chinese Petroleum officials said.
The vessel was anchored off northern Taiwan awaiting repairs to a pipeline system linking the offloading facility with CPC's north Taiwan refinery at Taoyuan, they said.
CPC officials said early on Monday that the refinery had a 10-day supply of crude and expected repairs to be completed in that time but would not give more a more specific timetable.
Details about the tanker and the specific source of its crude, identified only as African, were not immediately available.
Refinery officials said production from the facility would be slashed to 34 percent of capacity, effective immediately, and that the slowdown included a total shutdown of one of two topping units.

Officials declined to comment on the possibility that the slowing down of the refinery's operations indicated that repairs could take longer than the 10 days it could be expected to operate at full capacity with its current crude stores.
